intro: Choriantha popoviana, commonly known as the Popov's choriantha, is a rare flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescences and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils at high altitudes, showcasing adaptations to harsh environmental conditions. Its flowers are small and white, often clustered in dense umbels, and it produces small, dry fruits known as schizocarps. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
